importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of the article's publication, reflecting the most recent update on Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season, which includes game outcomes and player performances as of that date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This time frame covers the events of Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season, during which multiple dramatic comebacks, record-breaking performances, and quarterback benchings occurred, marking a pivotal moment in the season’s narrative.

keyTakeAways: Multiple teams, including the Denver Broncos and Green Bay Packers, executed late-game comebacks, with the Broncos becoming the first team in NFL history to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters.

Drake Maye broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (88.5%) with a 91.3% completion rate in a 31-13 win over the Tennessee Titans, becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game.

Quarterbacks were benched in multiple games — Tua Tagovailoa of the Miami Dolphins was replaced by rookie Quinn Ewers after three interceptions, and Justin Fields of the New York Jets was substituted at halftime due to poor first-half performance.
The New York Jets remain the only winless team in the NFL at 0–7 after their 13–6 loss to the Panthers, with head coach Aaron Glenn citing a need for a 'spark' in the offense.

The article highlights the increasing frequency of lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation (26 such instances through Week 7), the most in NFL history over that span, emphasizing the unpredictability and volatility of the current NFL season.

namedEntities.name: Drake Maye
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Drake Maye is central to the article as he broke Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage in a single game, marking a pivotal moment in the New England Patriots’ rebuilding phase and signaling a potential new era of quarterback excellence under head coach Mike Vrabel.

namedEntities.name: Tom Brady
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tom Brady’s legacy and record-setting performance in the 2009 season serve as a benchmark that Drake Maye surpassed, highlighting the significance of the milestone and the evolution of quarterback performance in the modern NFL.

namedEntities.name: Bo Nix
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bo Nix led a dramatic comeback by the Denver Broncos, becoming the first team in NFL history to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters, showcasing resilience and pivotal performance under pressure.

namedEntities.name: Jacoby Brissett
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Jacoby Brissett, playing as a backup for the Arizona Cardinals, was crucial in a close game against the Green Bay Packers, ultimately failing on the final drive despite a strong defensive effort by the Packers.

namedEntities.name: Tua Tagovailoa
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Tua Tagovailoa’s poor performance against the Cleveland Browns led to his benching in favor of rookie Quinn Ewers, illustrating declining performance and instability in the Miami Dolphins’ offense.

namedEntities.name: Justin Fields
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Justin Fields was benched at halftime during the Jets’ loss to the Panthers due to poor first-half performance, signaling a major shift in offensive leadership and raising concerns about team readiness and quarterback development.

namedEntities.name: Micah Parsons
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Micah Parsons, acquired by Green Bay from the Dallas Cowboys, dominated the Arizona Cardinals’ final drive with a third sack, showcasing his impact as a defensive force and contributing to a key late-game turnover.

namedEntities.name: Mike Vrabel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mike Vrabel, the head coach of the New England Patriots, was previously fired by the Tennessee Titans and now sees a resurgence in his team’s success, with Drake Maye’s performance marking a successful return and validation of his coaching philosophy.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Glenn
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Aaron Glenn, head coach of the New York Jets, made a mid-game decision to bench Justin Fields, reflecting the team’s struggles and the high stakes in addressing offensive ineptitude in a winless season.

namedEntities.name: Denver Broncos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Denver Broncos are highlighted for their historic comeback against the New York Giants, becoming the first team to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters.

namedEntities.name: Green Bay Packers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Packers made a late comeback against the Arizona Cardinals, winning 27-23, and with Micah Parsons’ defensive dominance, solidified their position as the top team in the NFC North.

namedEntities.name: New England Patriots
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Patriots were featured for their win over the Tennessee Titans, where Drake Maye achieved historic milestones, indicating a shift in franchise identity under new leadership.

namedEntities.name: Miami Dolphins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Dolphins suffered a devastating 31-6 loss to the Cleveland Browns, leading to the immediate benching of Tua Tagovailoa, marking a turning point in their season and raising concerns about their quarterback depth and offensive stability.

namedEntities.name: New York Jets
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Jets remain the only winless team in the league after a 13-6 loss to the Panthers, and their decision to bench Justin Fields highlights ongoing instability in both coaching and offensive execution.

namedEntities.name: Cleveland Browns
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Browns defeated the Miami Dolphins 31-6, contributing to a broader trend of teams facing collapse or recovery in late-game scenarios.

namedEntities.name: Carolina Panthers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Panthers defeated the New York Jets 13-6, highlighting their offensive resilience and the failure of the Jets’ offense to produce meaningful results.

namedEntities.name: Tennessee Titans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Titans lost to the New England Patriots 13-31, marking a key game in which Drake Maye achieved historic performance statistics.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Rams
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Rams played in London and won against the Jacksonville Jaguars, contributing to the season’s global reach and competitive depth.

namedEntities.name: San Francisco 49ers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 49ers defeated the Atlanta Falcons 20-10, contributing to the season’s competitive balance and showcasing a strong defensive performance.

namedEntities.name: Chicago Bears
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Bears beat the New Orleans Saints 26-14, adding to the narrative of unpredictable outcomes and late-game momentum shifts.

namedEntities.name: Kansas City Chiefs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Chiefs beat the Las Vegas Raiders 31-0, showing dominance in a high-scoring game and reinforcing their strength in the AFC.

namedEntities.name: Minnesota Vikings
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Vikings lost to the Philadelphia Eagles 22-28, illustrating the volatility of the season and late-game performance shifts.

namedEntities.name: Los Angeles Chargers
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Chargers lost to the Indianapolis Colts 24-38, contributing to the trend of late-game collapses and dramatic comebacks.

namedEntities.name: Dallas Cowboys
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Cowboys defeated the Washington Commanders 44-22, showcasing a dominant performance and a shift in team dynamics in the NFC East.

summaryOfNewsArticle: This Sunday’s Week 7 of the 2025 NFL season featured a surge in dramatic late-game comebacks and pivotal quarterback performances, including the Denver Broncos becoming the first team in NFL history to overcome a 19-point deficit after leading by 18 points in the first three quarters. Quarterback Drake Maye made history by surpassing Tom Brady’s franchise record for completion percentage (91.3% vs. 88.5%), becoming the first player in Super Bowl era to complete 90% of passes, throw over 200 yards, and rush for over 50 yards in a single game. Meanwhile, struggling quarterbacks such as Tua Tagovailoa of the Miami Dolphins and Justin Fields of the New York Jets were benched due to poor performances, signaling organizational instability. The article underscores the season’s unpredictability, with 26 lead changes in the final two minutes of regulation — the most in NFL history — and highlights the volatile nature of team success and failure in the modern NFL.
title: Historic and dramatic comebacks, second-year QB breaks Tom Brady record and high-profile benchings: NFL Week 7 Sunday review
